content.raw:
It looks like the 'branches not getting closed' problem might be a bug in bitbucket:

https://bitbucket.org/site/master/issues/14116/mercurial-cross-fork-pullrequests-dont

Or possibly bitbucket just not having made up their mind yet about how this functionality was intended to work. The feature seems a little poorly thought out the way it presently works, to be honest, it's like they put it in to meet a specific use case (requests to merge branches that are actually in the same repo as each other, where everyone has commit access) at the cost of it confusing everyone who didn't have that specific use case.

The bug report was recent-ish (4 months) and initiated by bitbucket staff (edit: who no longer works there...), so maybe a decent chance of being resolved. I've left a comment prodding them and explaining our situation.

The bug report was recent-ish (4 months) and initiated by bitbucket staff (edit: who no longer works there...), so maybe a decent chance of being resolved. I've left a comment prodding them and explaining our situation.

content.raw: I fairly strongly prefer mercurial because of its branching model (if only the hosting services supported it!) and because of tortoisehg. I use git sometimes and tried many GUIs for it but have yet to see anything come close to tortoisehg (and I don't buy the arguments that weaving and grafting a tree of commits is not greatly aided by a GUI, no matter how much of a command line geek one is). Github is pretty nice though. We'll see. I'd like to stay with mercurial if possible.

content.raw:
Yes, and this is appealing since we do so much back and forth in the branches while the pull request is being discussed that most of the history is pretty useless - but it visibly happens in the branch so it looks somewhat sensible still in the commit tree.

But since bitbucket presents squashing as a seeming alternative to a merge commit, it makes me wonder if the 'squashed' commit just appears in the default branch.

Maybe this would be a good way to start going about things, though it would leave the poor author of the pull request with an extra branch to prune, which is a bit unfriendly to newcomers still familiarising themselves with the tools.

Maybe time for some experiments.

Maybe time for some experiments.

content.raw:
1. is as you say messy as hell. 2 doesn't work for 'drive by' contributors who are not regular so can't be a general solution. 3. is annoying and seems vulnerable to us closing a branch too soon only to realise we need to put more commits in, although so far this is my favourite option. 4. Makes the tree of commits in tortoise hg have a huge number of extra lines on it bringing the branches forward to the point where they are closed.

I wonder what the 'squash' commit option in the menu that the merger sees does?

There is also 5. the merger pulls the branch in question from the author of the pull request, merges locally and then pushes the result to the main repo (this marks the pull request as merged). But that's pretty silly too, and the whole thing seems like a bit of a deficiency in bitbucket.
content.html:

Makes the tree of commits in tortoise hg have a huge number of extra lines on it bringing the branches forward to the point where they are closed.

I wonder what the 'squash' commit option in the menu that the merger sees does?

There is also 5. the merger pulls the branch in question from the author of the pull request, merges locally and then pushes the result to the main repo (this marks the pull request as merged). But that's pretty silly too, and the whole thing seems like a bit of a deficiency in bitbucket.

content.raw:
I see 4 options of which non seems great:

1. a repo for ech pull request (thats what I did at the beginning and it was messy as hell)
1. Each regular contributer becomes part of the team and merges their own request upon reaching enough approval (Not sure you guys want to give that much 'power' away)
1. Before merge ask the author to close the branches (this is really annoying)
1. regular pruning of merged branches (probably the best solution
content.html:
I see 4 options of which non seems great:

  1. a repo for ech pull request (thats what I did at the beginning and it was messy as hell)
  2. Each regular contributer becomes part of the team and merges their own request upon reaching enough approval (Not sure you guys want to give that much 'power' away)
  3. Before merge ask the author to close the branches (this is really annoying)
  4. regular pruning of merged branches (probably the best solution

content.raw:
Yes - I am actually struggling to find a single example where this closing worked like I thought it did. The only time bitbucket has actually closed the source branch is when I was merging my own pull request.

I thought that this is how it worked:

1. Main repo pulls from the fork

2. Main repo now has the extra branch

3. Main repo makes a "close branch" commit in the branch

4. Main repo makes a merge commit into the target branch

5. Author of the pull request does not see their fork's branch closed until they pull the commit that closed it from the main repo

The above doesn't require the merger to have commit access to the pull request author's fork. But bitbucket seems to only be closing the source branches when either the merger *does* have commit access to the fork, or where the merger is actually the author of the pull request.

Maybe this is fine for the bitbucket interface where it draws a distinction between active and merged branches, but in mercurial itself, typing 'hg heads' shows all branches.

I'll have to investigate and re-thing what the best workflow is here.
content.html:
Yes - I am actually struggling to find a single example where this closing worked like I thought it did. The only time bitbucket has actually closed the source branch is when I was merging my own pull request.

I thought that this is how it worked:

  1. Main repo pulls from the fork

  2. Main repo now has the extra branch

  3. Main repo makes a "close branch" commit in the branch

  4. Main repo makes a merge commit into the target branch

  5. Author of the pull request does not see their fork's branch closed until they pull the commit that closed it from the main repo

The above doesn't require the merger to have commit access to the pull request author's fork. But bitbucket seems to only be closing the source branches when either the merger does have commit access to the fork, or where the merger is actually the author of the pull request.

Maybe this is fine for the bitbucket interface where it draws a distinction between active and merged branches, but in mercurial itself, typing 'hg heads' shows all branches.

I'll have to investigate and re-thing what the best workflow is here.

update.description: This should ~~prevent problems that can occur because ```self.default_value``` is not defined at anytime but is referenced in ```StaticAnalogQuantity.static_value()``` and~~ make ```StaticAnalogQuantity.default_value``` user configurable.
update.title: Added default_value to StaticAnalogQuantity's constructor

content.raw:
Note that I would suggest the keyword argument in `Output` be `default_value=None`  and then only override the subclass defined `default_value` if is not None in order to preserve the output class specific Python type for `default_value`. All the subclasses define `default_value`. I believe they are all used for the initial value of the output if it isn't explicitly set at `t0`. Configuring this is important if you want your output to stay high, or at a particular value by default.

FYI, I just did a test, even with Python 3.4 with the keyword argument before `*args`, this means that `*args` can never contain anything. It thus only works (I think) if you use keyword arguments for everything (like `name=...`, `connection=...` , etc.)
content.html:
Note that I would suggest the keyword argument in Output be default_value=None and then only override the subclass defined default_value if is not None in order to preserve the output class specific Python type for default_value. All the subclasses define default_value. I believe they are all used for the initial value of the output if it isn't explicitly set at t0. Configuring this is important if you want your output to stay high, or at a particular value by default.

FYI, I just did a test, even with Python 3.4 with the keyword argument before *args, this means that *args can never contain anything. It thus only works (I think) if you use keyword arguments for everything (like name=..., connection=... , etc.)
